DeregistrationReasonOtherText: Edward operations have been combined with adjactent RMP facility 100000131993.

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
RISK MANAGEMENT PLAN EXECUTIVE SUMMARY
Targa Pipeline Mid-Continent Holdings LLC 
Edward Gas Plant (Facility ID: 100000226436)

ACCIDENT RELEASE PREVENTION AND RESPONSE POLICIES

Targa Pipeline Mid-Continent, WestTex, L.L.C. (Targa) owns and operates a natural gas processing facility, the Edward Gas Plant, in Upton County, Texas.  The plant is designed to process natural gas and recover liquid products from natural gas by physical separation and cryogenic means.  Both petroleum condensates and natural gas liquids are recovered from the inlet pipeline gas in this process for off-site sales.

The Edward Gas Plant is committed to worker and public safety.  This commitment is demonstrated by our efforts in accident prevention, such as training personnel, quality assurance, and considering safety in the design, installation, operation and maintenance of our process.  Our policy is to implement reasonable controls to prevent foreseeable releases of regulated substances.  However if a release does occur, facility trained personnel will evaluate the situation, take actions within the capabilities of the facility, and notify the necessary outside agencies. 

DESCRIPTION OF THE STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCE

The Edward Gas Plant is located near Midkiff, Texas in Upton County. Targa treats the entire gas plant as one process with 1,404,902 lbs of flammable mixtures. The facility operates the process to produce the following petroleum products:

1.	Y grade mixture from natural gas
2.	Stabilized Condensate
3.	Residue Gas
	
OFFSITE CONSEQUENCE ANALYSIS (OCA) RESULTS

The worst-case scenario (WCS) associated with a release of flammable substances at Edward Gas Plant is a vapor cloud explosion involving 275,399 pounds (60,000 gallons) of a flammable mixture contained in a Natural Gas Liquids Product Surge Tank (V-404).  Using the EPA's RMP COMP Version 1.07 program, the entire inventory is assumed to release and ignite, resulting in a vapor cloud exp

losion that reaches 1 psi overpressure point at 0.5 miles.  The rest of the vessels that were evaluated are located within and have a radius smaller than the WCS vessel discussed.  

The facility is not located within a populated area; therefore, the WCS would not affect a public receptor and is considered a Program 1 process.  The nearby Benedum Gas Plant is owned by Targa and is therefore not a public receptor despite being located within the WCS distance to endpoint.  A consideration of the 0.5 mile radius has been incorporated into our notification and emergency response planning. 

GENERAL ACCIDENT RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM

The Edward Gas Plant is covered by the OSHA Process Safety Management (PSM) Program to aid in accident release prevention.

FIVE YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY

The Edward Gas Plant is a new facility.  There have been no accidental releases from covered processes that resulted in death, injury or significant property damage on site, or known off site death, injury, evacuation, sheltering in place, property damage or environmental damage during this period.

EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM INFORMATION

The Edward Gas Plant is a Non-Responding Facility as per 48 CFR 68.90(b). The plant maintains a written emergency response plan, which is in place to help protect employees and public safety as well as the environment.  The plan identifies steps to be taken in case of an accidental release including: evacuation plans, accounting for personnel after an evacuation, and notification of Targa staff, local emergency response agencies, and the public if a release occurs. However, facility personnel are not trained to be first responders to large fires and should a release occur from one of the vessels the facility would rely on the local fire department to respond.  

Employees receive training in the procedures to be followed when certain employees must remain to operate critical plant operations before they evacuate.  The Edward Gas Plant has a

round-the-clock communications capability with appropriate emergency response organizations (Fire Department, Police and Sheriff's Office).  This interface provides the means of notifying the public of an incident, if necessary, as well as facilitating quick response to an incident.

ORGANIZATIONAL CHART

The following provides a facility organizational chart with respect to RMP responsibilities.

NAME: Clint Duty
TITLE: Vice President, Technical Services
REPORTS TO: Pat McDonnie, COO
RESPONSIBILITIES:  Oversight of RMP Implementation, release prevention, response recordkeeping, training, and inspections.

NAME: Ricky Young
TITLE: Area Manager
REPORTS TO: Dwayne Burks, Senior Vice President of Operations
RESPONSIBILITIES:  Assist the Primary Response Coordinator with the above listed responsibilities.

NAME: Wayne Wauson
TITLE: Operations Superintendent
REPORTS TO: Ricky Young, Area Manager
RESPONSIBILITIES:  Assist the Primary Response Coordinator with the above listed responsibilities

NAME: Jimmy Dalton
TITLE: Operations Supervisor
REPORTS TO: Wayne Wauson, Operations Superintendent
RESPONSIBILITIES:  Assist the Primary Response Coordinator with the above listed responsibilities.

NAME/TITLE: Lead Plant Operators
REPORTS TO: Jimmy Dalton, Operations Supervisor & Response Coordinators
RESPONSIBILITIES: Assist Coordinators with RMP implementation & report incidents

NAME/TITLE: Onsite Personnel
REPORTS TO: Lead Plant Operators & Response Coordinators
RESPONSIBILITIES: Good housekeeping, reporting maintenance issues & incidents

NAME/TITLE: Onsite Contractors
REPORTS TO: Response Coordinators
RESPONSIBILITIES: Good housekeeping, reporting maintenance issues & incidents 

PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY 

There are currently no planned changes to improve safety. Rather, the company believes that diligent compliance with our RMP Prevention Program forms the framework that allows for the continued improvement to the level of sa

fety at the Edward Gas Plant. Some of the key components of the program that will help maintain and, where applicable, improve safety are:

The Management of Change provisions ensure that we consider the potential safety and health impacts of any change we make to chemicals, technology, equipment or procedures.

The PHA provisions serve as a tool to ensure continual evaluation of potential hazards, thereby leading to continual improvements in our safety standards. 

The Mechanical Integrity provisions ensure that equipment and instrumentation are designed, constructed, installed and maintained to minimize the risk of hazardous release thereby serving as an integral part of our safety program.

Internal and third party compliance audits will ensure that we maintain and increase our level of safety protection.
